/work/doc/pages/PredefinedSchedulesAndConnectionSettings.md
Go to the documentation of this file.
1 \defgroup predefined-schedules-and-connection-settings Predefined Schedules and Connection Settings
2 \ingroup scheduler
3 
4 \details
5 
6 To simplify development, Session Scheduler provides an ability to define session schedules
7 and connecting settings in configuration files for later referencing in the source code.
8 
9 Once presets are defined in the file, the session scheduler can use them during the instance
10 initialization stage (OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedulerOptions class exposes
11 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionSchedulerOptions::configurationFile member for these purposes).
12 Afterwards, both schedules and connection settings can be referenced in the source code using the
13 string identifiers. Scheduler exposes the OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionScheduler::add overload
14 to schedule a session with parameters described in a configuration file.
15 \section preset-usage-example Example
16 
17 \snippet SessionScheduler.cpp PresetUsage
18 
19 Moreover, OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionScheduler exposes
20 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionScheduler::findSchedule and
21 OnixS::B3::BOE::Scheduling::SessionScheduler::findConnectionSettings members to access
22 real instances of schedules and connection settings described in the configuration file.
23 These members can help when a session has to be registered with a partially predefined
24 configuration.
25 
26 \section partial-preset-usage-example Example
27 
28 The following example demonstrates how a session can be registered with a predefined schedule,
29 but custom connection settings are not described in the configuration file.
30 
31 \snippet SessionScheduler.cpp PartialPresetUsage
32 
33 \section scheduler-configuration-file-reference Configuration File Reference
34 
35 Description of Scheduler settings has XML-based syntax. The following elements are supported:
36 
37 | Element | Description |
38 |---------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
39 | `SchedulerSettings` | Root element of scheduler's configuration. |
40 | `Schedules` | Contains descriptions of predefined schedules. |
41 | `Schedule` | Describes attributes of a particular session schedule.|
42 | `Connections` | Contains descriptions of predefined session connection settings.|
43 | `Connection` | Defines characteristics of a particular session connection.|
44 
45 
46 \note
47 Up-to-date [Scheduler settings configuration schema](https://ref.onixs.biz/fix/scheduler/scheduler-settings-1.6.xsd)
48 available on [Corporate Website](https://www.onixs.biz/).
49 
50 \subsection schedule-definition-example Defining Session Schedule
51 
52 Session Schedule description consists in definition of the following
53 attributes for the `Schedule` element:
54 
55 <!-- markdownlint-disable MD033 -->
56 
57 <table class="doxtable">
58 
59  <tr>
60  <th>Attribute</th>
61  <th>Values</th>
62  <th>Notes</th>
63  </tr>
64 
65  <tr>
66  <td>id</td>
67  <td>Non-empty String</td>
68  <td>
69  It's a unique identifier for the schedule.
70  The value of this attribute is used later in the source code to
71  refer to the described schedule. It must be unique among all
72  schedules.
73  </td>
74  </tr>
75 
76  <tr>
77  <td>firstDay</td>
78  <td>
79  <code>Sunday</code>,
80  <code>Monday</code>,
81  <code>Tuesday</code>,
82  <code>Wednesday</code>,
83  <code>Thursday</code>,
84  <code>Friday</code>,
85  <code>Saturday</code>
86  </td>
87  <td>
88  Defines the first day of the activity week for session.
89  </td>
90  </tr>
91  <tr>
92  <td>lastDay</td>
93  <td>
94  <code>Sunday</code>,
95  <code>Monday</code>,
96  <code>Tuesday</code>,
97  <code>Wednesday</code>,
98  <code>Thursday</code>,
99  <code>Friday</code>,
100  <code>Saturday</code>
101  </td>
102  <td>
103  Defines the last day of the activity week for session.
104  </td>
105  </tr>
106  <tr>
107  <td>logonTime</td>
108  <td>
109  Time value from 0:00 till 23:59 in 24
110  hours format (with optional seconds resolution).
111  </td>
112  <td>
113  Defines the time of logon for a session.
114  </td>
115  </tr>
116  <tr>
117  <td>logoutTime</td>
118  <td>
119  Time value from 0:00 till 23:59 in 24
120  hours format (with optional seconds resolution).
121  </td>
122  <td>
123  Defines the time of logout for a session.
124  </td>
125  </tr>
126 
127 </table>
128 
129 \subsection connection-settings-definition Defining Session Connection Settings
130 
131 The description of connection settings consists of the definition of the
132 following attributes for the `Connection` element:
133 
134 <table class="doxtable">
135 
136  <tr>
137  <th> Attribute </th>
138  <th> Values </th>
139  <th> Notes </th>
140  </tr>
141 
142  <tr>
143  <td> `id` </td>
144  <td>Non-empty String</td>
145  <td>
146  It's a unique identifier for the settings set.
147  The value of this attribute is used later in the
148  source code to refer to described settings.
149  It must be unique among all settings sets.
150  </td>
151  </tr>
152 
153  <tr>
154  <td> `host` </td>
155  <td>String</td>
156  <td>
157  If a session must be logged on in the role of initiator,
158  this parameter defines a remote host to which the session
159  must connect to. Otherwise, the attribute is ignored.
160  </td>
161  </tr>
162  <tr>
163  <td> `port`</td>
164  <td>Number</td>
165  <td>
166  If a session must be logged on in the role of initiator,
167  this parameter defines a port number to which the session
168  must connect to. Otherwise, the attribute is ignored.
169  </td>
170  </tr>
171 
172 </table>
173 
174 <!-- markdownlint-enable MD033 -->
175 
176 \note
177 It's possible to specify multiple counter parties in session connection
178 settings description. If Scheduler fails to connect session to
179 one counterparty, it will switch, using another one and so on, until a successful
180 connection will be established. For this reason, the session connection settings
181 XML description accepts inner `Counterparty` nodes with
182 `host` and `port` attributes.
183 Inner nodes are ignored if the master `Connection` node contains `host` and `port` attributes.
184 
185 \subsection scheduler-configuration-file-referenceExample Example
186 
187 Below is a typical configuration file for Sessions Scheduler.
188 
189 ~~~{.xml}
190 <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
191 <SchedulerSettings
192  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
193  xsi:schemaLocation="https://ref.onixs.biz/fix/scheduler https://ref.onixs.biz/fix/scheduler/scheduler-settings-1.6.xsd"
194  xmlns="https://ref.onixs.biz/fix/scheduler" >
195 
196  <Schedules>
197 
198  <Schedule
199  id="B3"
200  firstDay="Sunday"
201  logonTime="18:00"
202  lastDay="Friday"
203  logoutTime="16:00"
204  />
205 
206  <Schedule
207  id="SimpleDaily"
208  firstDay="Monday"
209  lastDay="Friday"
210  logonTime="08:00"
211  logoutTime="17:00"
212  />
213 
214  </Schedules>
215 
216  <Connections>
217  <Connection
218  id="LocalSession">
219  <Counterparty host="localhost" port="4500"/>
220  </Connection>
221  <Connection
222  id="SessionToTestingEnvironment">
223  <Counterparty host="testing-evn.privatedomain.com" port="8000"/>
224  </Connection>
225  <Connection
226  id="MultiTargetSession">
227  <Counterparty host="primary.domain.com" port="4600"/>
228  <Counterparty host="secondary.domain.com" port="4500"/>
229  </Connection>
230  </Connections>
231 </SchedulerSettings>
232 ~~~
